Text: The bill is supported by @uscattlemen, @BeefUSA, @RCALFUSA, @SDCattlemen and SD Stockgrowers. It‚Äôs not often that you have all the cattle groups supportive of the same idea, which says a lot. I thank Sen. Tester for his leadership and am hopeful others will get behind this effort
Consumers should feel confident that their beef is safe. Foreign beef should not jeopardize the high-quality beef produced by American ranchers.

Brazilian beef poses a threat to both American consumers and producers. I'm joining @SenatorTester on legislation that would suspend Brazilian beef imports to the United States until experts can conduct a systematic review of the commodity‚Äôs safety.

Senators Manchin and Sinema, joined with every @SenateGOP member, acting to preserve the current rules of the Senate which require bipartisan approval of legislation and which protects the minority rights as our Founders envisioned.
Democrat Senate leadership just lead their caucus on a failed mission to significantly alter Senate rules in an attempt to pass their liberal agenda on a simple majority vote.
Republicans believe in local control and common sense. That‚Äôs right!
Our Founding Fathers knew that confidence in the integrity of our elections could best be protected at the local level - not by a federal bureaucrat.
Democrats believe that taxpayer money should subsidize federal elections. That‚Äôs wrong!
Democrats think that elected state officials should be subject to federal bureaucratic oversight over any election decisions. That‚Äôs wrong!
Democrats want to force states to allow convicted felons to vote. That‚Äôs wrong!
Democrats want you to show your ID with proof of vaccination to participate in society, yet don‚Äôt think you need an ID to vote. That‚Äôs wrong!

There are many interesting moves being made in the field of CCs. It very much is the Wild West of finance. They make new things possible, which isn‚Äôt always a good thing. They can have consequences no one expected. This field deserves a great deal of attention going forward.

So how does this relate to Colonial Pipeline? Bitcoins only exist as data. They can be tied to digital wallets rather than a specific person‚Äôs identity, which means people believe they can receive and spend them anonymously- perfect for secret transactions like ransoms.

This means that, as bitcoin gets more valuable, more people mine, mining gets harder, it takes more computations and more electricity to mine a bitcoin. Some of you may be familiar with @elonmusk recent statement about bitcoin‚Äôs carbon footprint.

In short, the more miners there are, the harder it is to mine bitcoins. Since the best way to mine is to simply use more computations, there is an incentive to pool as much effort into mining as possible, simply to make sure your pool has an advantage over other miners.

The interesting thing is that you can make it easier or harder to form new blocks if you make the nonce higher or lower. And for bitcoin, the difficulty is adjusted every 2016 blocks so that the rate of formation of new blocks is constant.

Despite the randomness, it's more like they‚Äôre getting paid a fee to maintain ledgers than mining or creating bitcoins. Miners provide proof that they‚Äôve done work to contribute to the chain in exchange for compensation (in bitcoins), rather than making bitcoins themselves.

The first person to win a block gets a prize of bitcoins. Since the second step in forming a block is essentially up to chance, the most effective way to mine is simply to throw more computation at the problem, verifying as many blocks as possible as fast as possible.

You may ask ‚Äúwhy not just guess 000‚Ä¶0001 for your hash, if the goal is to get a hash below the target nonce?‚Äù The answer: your guess is put through what is basically a randomizing equation based on several inputs, like the timestamp. Guessing your hash ahead of time is #noncense

In short, mining a new bitcoin is a two-step process. First, you need to verify a block‚Äôs worth of transactions, then you need to guess a hash (a number). Your guess is compared to a target (called a nonce) and if your guess is below the nonce then you form a block.

Since #bitcoins are decentralized, there isn‚Äôt a government or bank to maintain the system, which means there needs to be a different way. People who verify transactions are bitcoin miners, and the process of verification is fundamental to how they make (or mine) new bitcoins.

These protocols revolve around cryptography (for computers, this is the use of math to code information) hence ‚Äúcrypto‚Äùcurrencies. However, someone needs to actually verify each new block in the chain to keep the system running smoothly.

This blockchain of transactions forms a distributed ledger that is difficult to modify and easy to verify (in theory); a ledger that is maintained collectively on a network with specific protocols to verify each new block in the chain, meaning that bitcoin exchanges are secure.

Using bitcoin as an example: bitcoins exist in digital ledgers, but to prevent fraudulent exchanges, transactions are recorded in encrypted blocks. Each block points at the previous block and has a timestamp. Go where each block points and you get a chain, called a ‚Äúblockchain‚Äù.

The software used to make new CCs exists and is publicly available, which means that developing a new CC can be done in as little as a few hours. Honestly, it looks like a return to the days when each bank printed their own notes.

CCs exist only in digital ledgers and wallets rather than as physical objects like dollar bills. Like all fiat currencies, they have value only because people agree they do, but CCs in general lack the backing of a government or central bank.

Some people decided that, if the commodity backing a currency doesn‚Äôt matter, then why should money need to be a physical object and why should you need a government (or bank) to back money? From there, some programmers started developing cryptocurrencies (CCs).

Some history: in the last century governments have moved away from commodity currencies (such as gold) to fiat currencies (such as Federal Reserve notes) cementing the idea that money can have value just because people agree it does.

Software developments, however, mean that they don‚Äôt need to bother with masks and voice modulators. They can issue a ransom and request payment with a cryptocurrency (CC) (like bitcoin) rather than exchange a briefcase full of cash.

Hostage and ransom payments are a practice that has been applied in different contexts for thousands of years, ranging from prisoner exchanges to kidnappings. Today, a person collecting a ransom payment does not want their identity publicly tied to a ransom.

Thread: Recently, I tweeted about the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack. Since then, the Colonial Pipeline network has returned to normal operations, but I realize that there was one question I didn‚Äôt answer. Specifically: how do ransomware ransoms get paid?

Silence only helps bad actors. Sharing info about attacks, exploits or vulnerabilities allows us to find trends in attacks, share effective responses, and respond effectively to the fast-pace and evolving threat of cyberattack.

In this rapidly evolving environment the federal government has a role to play. To start, 
@CISAgov has tools and resources available to help protect networks (https://t.co/FSv3GxbcAv) and implement best practices (https://t.co/tYjp1gMokV)
Citizens, companies, and even local and state governments are vulnerable to cyberattacks and need to be prepared in advance to deal with them.

Ransomware has been on the rise for a long time, but increases in teleworking have exposed existing cyber vulnerabilities in many companies‚Äô systems. We see from Colonial Pipeline that such vulnerabilities can impact even the largest companies.

Ransomware is malware that infects a computer system and locks it down, preventing it from working. It holds the system ‚Äúhostage‚Äù until a ransom is paid. Pipelines aren‚Äôt unique; ransomware can target digital records, ordinary servers or even traffic lights.
The first is the rise of ransomware attacks, the second (which I plan to discuss more at a later date) is the vulnerability of critical infrastructure.

While not a replacement for Colonial Pipeline‚Äôs full network, this waiver and several smaller lines that are in operation should buy time to restore full function. This incident illustrates two problems at once.

The attack has caused shutdowns across their network, a problem that is exacerbated by rising demand for fuel as the economy recovers. To help combat supply issues, the Department of Transportation issued a temporary waiver to ease trucking of oil products to impacted areas.
Thread: You may have seen the news this weekend about the ransomware attack on Colonial Pipeline, which is responsible for providing ~45% of the East Coast‚Äôs supply of diesel, petrol and jet fuel.
